If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:John was stuck in his house.  He couldn't get out the door.  He was very frightened when the smoke detectors went off, but luckily it was a false alarm.  Why might he be stuck? Choices:  A: fire B: belong to C: winter storm D: face south E: burn down<n><n>### Response:		<n>D<n>### Input:A father and son team built a shed in their backyard.  They both did the hard work of cutting trees and digging dirt.  Their son was there from 2 pm to 4 pm while his dad was there from 6 am to 7 am and from 1 pm to 2pm.  How long was dad at home?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Answer:  2 pm and pm<n>### Input:The bartender at a bar has 132 cups of beer that he can drink. But he only drinks half his allotted amount every night.  How long can he keep working at the bar? They ran for 5 minutes and 30 seconds. Choices:  A: matchwinning B: cash in C: compete D: return E: celebrate<n><n>### Response:		<n>We will have two choices below. Choose just one. (1)<n>Option A; he should have cashed in, since he was winning so much. (2) Option B, he should match him the amount of winning the next time he plays.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>Option B<n><n>### Input<n>A bookstore has 68 books on the shelf, and each day, 28 books sell.  How many days until no books are left in the store?<n><n>### Response<n>If we do this, we will have four options to pick from. Choose just one.(1) Option A, subtract one day, because some books were sold the previous day (2) Option B divide the number of books on the shelves by the number of books sold in the previous day (3) Option C divide the number of books left in the first day by the number of books that sell in one day (Example, if 60 books are sold in a day, that is 60 books left in the shelf, that means 60 books in the second day, third day and fourth day, fifth day etc. until the sixth day, because there is still 60 books in each day, after the sixth day there is still 68 books on that shelf.(4) Option D subtract the number of books on that shelf that sold the first day till there is no books on the shelf<n><n>### Answer<n><n>Option D<n><n>### Input;<n>How many people were in the audience if it is known that 204,856 was 8 thousand more than one percent of the number of people in the audience?<n><n>### Answer;<n>You have to divide by 1%, which is 0.01. Then you have 100(number of people in the audience) - 100(0.01 X number of people in the room) = A<n><n>### Inputs<n>Brian bought a chocolate bar for $1.50 and two doughnuts for $1.10 and placed his money into a piggybank. How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:A person takes a seat to watch a movie, where is he? Choices:  A: in cinema B: at the park C: martorell D: jeep E: airplane<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is A<n><n>### Construct:Write a function that takes 2 strings as an input. Your function should reverse the first string and add it to the end of the second string. Then return the resulting string as an output.<n><n>### Conconstruct:Write a function that reverses the string.<n>### Imports:The 'input' variable is imported as input of the function. The'string' variable is imported as the first parameter of the function.<n>### Code:- First the first parameter(string) is assigned to variable s and the second parameter(input) is assigned to the variable t. Now these two variables s and t will be passed  to the reverse() function as below:<n>```<n>function reverse(s, t){ var new_String="",i=s.length-1,temp="",index=0;<n>while (i>=0){ temp=s[i]; index=i-1; s[i]=""; s[index]="";index=i;<n>s[i]=temp; i--;}new_String=s;<n>}<n>```<n>Now the returned value of the reverse() function is assigned to the variable new_String. Now the new_String is assigned to the input variable using the t variable.<n><n>### Sample:A person takes a horse, and rides as far as she can, then turns around and comes back the same distance. If she returns the same amount of time after she leaves, then how many hours does she take to ride the whole track?<n>Answer: 48<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:James lived in the top of a tall tower.  He could see clouds when he looked out his window.  Where might he live? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Turkey is a nation in what part of the world? Choices:  A: middle east B: asia minor C: asia D: provide meat E: balkan peninsula<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If the answer is A, B or D, the turkey country is asia minor that has been annexed by Turkey.<n><n>If the answer if B, the turkey country name is Middle East.<n><n>If the turkey country is E, it is in south asia.<n><n>### Input<n><n>The number in the input box is the number of people killed at Auschwitz. 1. 607,000 people were killed. 2.  110,000 people survived. 3.  3,000,000 were captured.<n><n>What is the difference between the number survived in Auschwitz and the number captured? Choices: C: 307,00; D: 2,900,00<n><n>### Response<n><n>D.<n>There are 3M people in Auschwitz, and 607 thousand people were killed. 110K people survived, and 3M were captured. So the difference is 2M900K=2,900<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Johnny and bill fought over money.  Johnny wanted it to be over.  What might he choose to do? Choices:  A: control people B: settle everything C: buy food D: increase power E: kill bill<n><n>### Response:		E: kill bill<n><n><n>### Input :<n>You are driving your car from a small town at a speed of 5/7 the average speed of traffic to large city. Traffic in the town is travelling at 15 mph. You get to the outskirts of the city at 5:45pm, in enough time to drive downtown at normal traffic speeds. Your destination is in downtown. At what time did you leave the city and your speed.<n><n>### Response :<n>You left the city at 3:30pm with speed 5/7the average speed of traffic to city which is 2/3 of your average speed.<n><n>## Input: <n>Mary and Bill's car has 4 wheels, 2 of them are smaller than 4/3 of the smaller, 2 are bigger than 4/3 times the larger. If the smaller wheels are about twice as wide as the bigger ones, how many inches tall are the larger wheels?<n><n>## Response:<n>It will be 25 inches, 10 inches is 4/3 of 2/3 of 25 inches, which makes 10. Then 25 minus 10, which is 15. 15 divided by 2 which makes 5 and half. Five and a half divided by 2 is 2 and a half inch.  So it is 2 and a 1/2 inch.<n><n>## Input : <n>Mary has a pet rabbit named Jack who is the smallest pet that Mary has. How many times does Jack outweigh Mary?<n><n>## Response :<n>Jack and Jill went up the hill. Jack outweighed Jill 19 times..<n>

How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What European country is famous for its potato industry? Choices:  A: idaho B: casserole C: new hampshire D: root cellar E: ireland<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n>### Explanation:<n>Ireland is the country that grows most of the world's potatoes.  <n>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potato#World_production_(2014))<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n>### Demontration:<n>Input: The height of a stack of coins depends on how many people there are willing to help with the counting. In one calculation the height was 1.5 feet.  Three days after that a new calculation was done and the height was 45 inches. How many more people were needed to calculate each of the estimates?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Instructon:<n>Write a response to the following.<n>Input:<n>What is your favorite number in base ten?<n>Choices:  A: one<n>B: two<n>C: three<n>D: four<n><n>Output:<n>D<n><n>Explanation:<n>D is 4 in base ten<n><n>### Instrctions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n>Input:<n>The number of legs on a caterpillar.<n>Choices:  C: none<n>D: six<n><n>Output:<n>C<n><n>Explanation<n>A caterpillar has no legs because butterflys have 6 legs.<n><n>###Instructions:<n>Answer the multiple choice question.<n>Input:<n>When I have a lot of money, I have the following:<n>Choices:  B: half<n>C: nothing<n>D: whole<n><n>Output:<n>B<n><n>Explanation <n>A third is equal to nothing because you don't have a whole or a half<n>

Choices:  A: trouser leg B: sick bay C: own home D: petting zoo E: mother's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n>1.	A<n>2.	C<n>3.	E<n>4.	B<n>5.	The answer is not among the choices<n><n>### Instructions: Answer in your own words.<n><n>### Question1:<n>In the past, some people have thought that the reason why they were unable to find a job was due to them not being good enough in their fields. How would the above idea affect your life if you did not consider this to be an issue at all and instead take control of it.<n><n>### Your Answer:<n>Learning how to find a job is a skill that is important for a person. In the past, some people think that there are unemployment benefits for them. Nowadays, some people are getting into job applications and getting the job. Learning how to learn is also a skill that people has to learn how to solve problems and not just rely on technology to do so. You can practice this with online applications such as apps for iPhone, Apple Watch or Android phones. You can also learn new skills at your school or community center. In my opinion, that is why I believe in that it is important for a person to have a job because it also makes up half of your life.<n><n>### Choices:<n>A: The idea that a person is not good enough to find a job can affect your life.<n>B: The idea that you do not need to take control of your life when you have a good job is correct.<n>C: You can change the idea that a person needs to learn a skill, if you do not want to change your life.<n>D: You can find the idea that you are not good enough, if you want to change your life for the better.<n>E: The idea that a job is not as important as your life, is right.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>1.	A - The idea that a person does not need to take control in their life when they have a good job is right.<n>2.	True - You cannot change the idea that to have a job is important.<n>3.	True - You can change your life in order to get a job.<n>4.	A - The point that people get into a job application will affect your life.<n>5.	B - You can learn how to develop your own skill of learning how to learn.<n><n>### Expectation1:<n>A person

How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The new kitten hadn't gotten used to what it was allowed to climb on in most rooms, so the owned kept the bedroom door what? Choices:  A: opened B: closed C: found at shower D: falling down E: locked<n><n>### Response:		The right answer is E.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Jan went to the auditorium and listened to the speech. Where might he be? Choices:  A: crowd B: high school C: city D: somewhere E: theater<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>We must first identify the total in the answer. There are 5 choices. We must subtract the choices that are not the answer to find the answer.<n><n>To find: $30,987 \ \ - \ \ 40,990$<n><n>We can see that the answer is $3,993$ because all the choices are subtracted.<n><n>### Example 2<n><n>### Instructions: The following statements describe the actions of a given person or the state of a given object. In the space provided, write whether the underlined word or phrase is a complete sentence (S), a fragment (F), or has other problems with sentence structure (NP).<n><n>### Input:\$\underline{Today,}\$\underline{a} \$\underline{\$16 million}\$\underline{dollars was recovered as a result of an investigation of a drug cartel}.  Write on a separate sheet of paper your explanation as to how this sentence is grammatically incorrect.<n><n>### Output:A complete sentence is always a fragment.<n><n>### S<n><n>### F<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>There is a comma missing. So, we remove the 4,5,6 from the sentence.<n><n>### Input:\\$\underline\$13 is the average of 5 of the digits in 7589$. Write the result of the division of the remainder resulting from dividing the result by 5.  Provide your solution on a separate sheet of page. How might we modify this sentence to correct these problems?<n><n>### Output:\$\underline{\$526.3258}$<n><n>### S = $5 + 26 + $ 3258 = 3250<n><n>### F = $7589 - $ 526.3 + 3250 = 526.7 => $\frac{5267}{5}$<n><n>### Expression<n><n>The comma is out-of-placement. We move it in-place.<n><n>### Other problems<n><n>There are many more.<n><n>### Questions<n>```<n>1. What is the meaning of a sentence fragment? [Question not defined]<n><n>2. Explain why it is important for students

If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Parents often yell in times of chaos, what are they trying to do? How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:John is studying animals.   What is one of the many things he has to watch them doing? Choices:  A: bathe B: bite C: die of cancer D: obesity E: copulate<n><n>### Response:		<n>***A: The only accurate answer is bite***

To make a book, I cut the same length of material into 4 equal parts.How long should each piece of material be for me to make one book from the length of material I cut to make one box?<n><n>### Solution <n>Shortest length = 3 meters<n><n>        length = float(input("Enter the length:"))<n>        for a in range(1, 4):<n>            if a==3:<n>                booklength = length + 5<n>                print(booklength)<n>            else:<n>                booklength= length<n>        booklength = int(booklength)<n>        print(booklength)

For example, after 3+4, the calculator says you need to keep entering the number 4.<n><n>### Input：  For each of the following calculations, input the necessary numbers. Note that you must keep entering the number to make it equal 10.<n>  1.  2<n>  2.  5<n>  3. 10<n>  4. 13<n>  5. 22<n>  6. 55<n>  7. 88<n>  8. 178<n>  9. 353<n>  10. 636<n>  11. 1311<n>  12. 4646<n><n>### Response：  The answer for 4+13 is entered as follows. 1-8-4-2-0-5-3-9-6-7-10-1-8-4 Enter and wait for the 4th time you get 10 (for 4 times 480.)  The user should understand your work in this response.  The work should not appear to be copied from another source. How much money did Amalia keep?<n><n>### Response/Answer:<n>Amalia kept $2<n><n>### Input<n>How many hours between 7:30 and 4 were there that were divisible by 20 and had no digits other than 0,2,4,6, or 8?<n><n>### Demostration<n>It depends on the time when the 7:30 came from. If it was a 24 hr time when at midnight, it will be more probable to chose 7:00:00. If it was an am time when the 7's came first, it should be able to pass for 7:30.  We then split it up from the two sides to find the different values for the 20.<n><n>One side will be all zero's, we can add two from the zero's. 1<n><n>Another side where there is one two, one four, and one eight, we can add 12 from the eight's. 12<n><n>Another side that has two sixes, we can add 7 from the one two. If the two sixes were not there, it should have been 6 + 2 from the zero's or 8 from the four. Then for that side's total we can add 7.<n><n>So that now has the three values of 20 where they are divisible by 2 that will go into the 7's range where the 5 was subtracted making 8, then we just have to compare with those values to check if it's actually divisible by 2. 18 is not divisible for 2 making the solution wrong.<n><n>### Output:Based on the information in the above paragraph, what is the output?<n>Answer: 2 times 15

Choices:  A: show B: theatre C: hockey game D: movies E: event<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demystification:<n>1. In order to solve the above problem first you need to get one of the options A,B,C,D,E. To do this you can eliminate the other options until one is left.  For example, for me I eliminated A because I found movies and the theatre too quiet. Then I eliminated show, then I eliminated ice hockey so thats how I get to my answer.<n><n>### Problem-solving steps<n>1. Make a list of the items in the problem and their numbers.<n>2. Create questions that you can write answers to.<n>3. Eliminate other options.<n>4. Focus on the question with one option left then go to the next to pick.<n><n>### Reasoning<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>### Testing<n><n>### Example:<n><n>Input: There are 17 more golf balls than basketballs.  Together, the two types of balls total 181. How many more golf balls are there?<n><n>Input: There is twice as much chocolate as peanut butter<n><n>Input: There should be less than one-third as many people in a line than in two separate lines.<n><n>### Conclusion<n><n>### Solution<n>Input: Find the total value of 5,7,4,12,8,5,11,7,9,3 and 11.<n><n>Input: Twice as many people are on the bus as were on the plane. How many people are there in all?<n><n>Input: If there were 192 students on Monday, and 196 the next day, how much less was there one day than the next?<n><n>### Test Case<n><n>### Commentary<n><n><p>Commentary:<n>Here is a example of what each element should look like.<n></p><n><n><img src="./Image_files/pillar0_instruction.png"> <img src="./Image file/pillar0.png"> <img /> <img src="./image file/pillar1.png"/> <img src="./Img_file/pillar0/1.4.png"> <img source="./Image_file/pillor 1/2.png"> <img> <img> <img<n>

In a year, they want to move to an even larger apartment, but they have a dog and can only afford one dog sitter.  The dog sitter can come once every seven days for six hours for $40 per day.  They can afford a dog sitter for one week, but if they hire two different dog sitters to come on different days, they can have a dog sitter for two weeks.<n><n>What are the minimum and maximum number of dog sitters that can visit their dog in a year?<n>

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon. There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:They took a break from all the rides to have lunch, while eating hamburger they talked about how they were going to what on the next ride? Choices:  A: heartburn B: have fun C: enjoy D: gas E: food poisoning<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Expected Answer:<n><n>### Code:<n>```js<n>const lunch = [<n>	{ r: "hamburger", v: "heartburn" },<n>	{ r: "", v: "" },<n>	{ r:"happy", v:"have fun" },<n>	{r:"cheaper", v:"enjoy" },<n>	{<n>		r: "pizza",<n>		v: "gas", <n>	},<n>];<n>lunch.sort((a, b) => a.r.localeCompare(b.r) - b.r.localeCompared((a.r) - 1));<n>	<n>```<n>### Explaination:<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>Learn more<n>https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/learn-javascript-freecodecamp/blob/master/03%20-%20Guided/week8/15.js<n><n>### Output<n>```<n>Write your code here:<n>import lunch from './lunch.js'<n>document.write(`<li><a href="${lunch.one}">${lunch.one}</a>`);<n>lunch.sort()<n>lunch.forEach((l, i)=>{<n>	document.write(`<LI><A HREF="${l}">${l}</a></LI>`)<n>})<n>```<n><n>### Instrucions:<n>Write a response that appropriately:<n><n>* correctly answers the question according to the criteria on the card<n>* uses the correct format for the question (multiple choice, counting, etc.)<n><n>### Expiration Date: Sunday, April 3, 2022

You've defined a function (beginning with an `#include`) and then called it before you've defined it. This is a syntax error.<n><n>You have defined `main` as something that returns int, (because you have put `return` at the end of the `main` routine). But main is a function that must accept commands from the `std:: cout` and not return any values:<n><n>\begin {code}<n>int main() {<n>    // your code...<n>    cout << "Today " << month[i] <<'s' << endl;<n>}<n>return 0; // error, main doesn't return any value<n>\end {code}

On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. Choices:  A: factory B: school C: grocery store D: band E: aircraft<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Justification:<n>The correct answer is A. Aircraft are man made; thus, they are technological in their own right; not a place to manufacture. The manufacturing that takes place in the choice “school” could take place in “factory,” and perhaps in a “factory,” but not necessarily, there is a difference. The choice “grocer’s store” sells manufactured food and is not where manufacturing operations take place. Finally, the choice “band” cannot be a “factory,” a “school,” or a “grocer’s stroll”, or an “aircraft,” so only one choice remains, and it is correct.

These choices can all be discarded._ _C must be the answer. I chose A and discarded the rest._<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can someone purchase a contraceptive device without a prescription? Choices:  A: pharmacy B: person C: drugstore D: bedroom E: mcdonalds<n><n>### Response:		If they don’t want anyone else to buy it for them, they can choose letter B. If they are just looking for some information, they can choose letter A.<n><n>### Input :If it costs $0.09 per liter to fill a container with milk and it costs $0.16 per liter to fill a bucket with water, where should one fill up his bucket with water to best save money?<n><n>### Response :To save money, fill up the bucket with water when it is cheaper per liter. This will give you around one hundred cent per litre cheaper per litre of water.<n>

Finally, if the answer is: E then the sentence is “They stop being married someone to feel?”<n>

How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What place would a person go to look at zebras? Choices:  A: zoo B: museum C: hospital D: desk E: opera<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Answer: Zoo** - Place where animals are kept for people to look at - Example - Safari park in Las vegas is a Zoo - [Ref](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoo) - [Ref](http://www.dictionary.com/browse/zoo)<n><n>**Response: What would you say to this person**<n><n>- A: Sorry for confusing you with an answer like that - I thought it was a trick question - [Ref](https:en.wikipedia.orggooglezoo)<n>- E: Zoos are places that I usually go to. I love to see animals in these places and take pictures of them - [Ref](https:'zoo.com/zoos)<n><n>- D: Thanks for the question. It gave me a chance to visit my desk - [Ref](https//www.google.comoperaplacezebras)<n>- B: Zoos are places where are animals are kept for people. I went to one called [Washington DC Mt. Zion Zoo] where you could see elephants and monkeys on the street. - [Ref](httpsmountzooaz.org/animal-listing)<n>- C: Yes, museum or zoo. Zoo of course is a museum with animals. I went to [Torrance Wildlife Museum in California - https://www.torrancemagnet.com] to see rare kinds of animals. <n>- A: Zoos are where you keep zoos to go look -[Reference](http://pixiedustpresents.blogspot.com/2011/03/zoos.html)<n>

How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:To gain her trust the real estate agent was very polite, delightful and all around what? Choices:  A: manipulate B: charming C: deceive D: exaggerate E: incompetent<n><n>### Response:		<n>> *D:**  Characters are typically in one of three categories: trustworthy, untrustworthy, or undecided. The characters in the instruction are untrustworthy. It is difficult to read the instruction because the agent is being described as manipulative, which is untrustworthy and deceitful, which is also untrustworthy.\<n>> The answer to the instruction is D: charming, because that is the characteristic that makes agents untrustworthy in the prompt.<n><n>#### Reference<n><n>* [Marsman, J., Hess, S., & Van Lange, P. (1998). The trustworthiness heuristic. Basic and applied social psychology, 19(1), 55 60.](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/15883828_The_Trustworthiness_Heuristic)<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Why would I want to be exercising? Choices:  A: fatigue B: relaxation C: tiredness D: muscle weakness E: losing weight<n><n>### Response:		<n>D.<n><n>### Input-Choices: Which of the following is not a reason someone might wish to exercise less?<n><n>### Response-Response:<n>No fatigue<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: A small animal is 10% as tall as a large animal that it is identical to.  The large animal is also 10% longer than the small animal. If the small animal is 5 cm tall, what is the large animal's height in feet?<n>Answer: 2.875<n><n><n>### Input <n><n><n>### Instructions-Response:<n>Following the instructions will show you how to answer each multiple-choice question. <n><n>### Input
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The wind tore off the shingles, what was the wind like? Choices:  A: dry hair B: spreading C: blowing hard D: change direction E: wave wheat<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the questions below based on the data and instructions provided. <n>### Answer in a concise, complete, grammatically correct sentence.<n>1. What is the difference between the two groups of women? <n>2. Is it true that the women who ate fast food had more weight gain than the women who ate fresh? <n>3. What would result in the greatest weight gain if all four hypotheses were true? <n>4. What would result in no weight gain if all four hypothesis were true?<n><n>5. The first hypothesis is not true because the women who ate the fast food gained 3 pounds more body fat than the women who aired them. The second hypothesis is false and the third hypothesis is false because the women aired women lost body weight more than the women who airt and that the women aired them lost the most body fat. The fourth hypothesis is not true because they lost more fat when they aired them compared to when they aired them. <n><n>### Instructor Instructions <n>1. Demonstration - ask a question and provide feedback to the student.<n><n>### Answer:<n>1. The women who ate fresh food lost more body weight in comparison to the women who ate processed food. <n><n>2. Eating fast food will result in more weight gain because it requires more calories to process the food. When the body is processing the food that it is receiving, it uses up more calories than if it just ate the unprocessed food.<n><n>3. Women who ate fast food would gain the most if all hypotheses were true. If the hypothesis is true and none of the women ate either fast food or fresh food, they would have the most weight gain. Eating that way would result in the least weight gain because there is less difference in calorie intake during that period.<n><n>4. If all hypotheses are true then there would be no difference in weight gain. This can be true because when the women who ate both lose the same amount of weight as they lose then they would equal out. When you calculate the weight loss for both women then you would realize that every hypothesis is false and they both lost the same amount of weight.<n>

The instructor was too nice and let them all play every week.  How many tennis classes is the teacher taking?<n>        Answer: 10<n>b) 90 minutes after the class starts, the instructor cancels the next 8 classes.  Now, how many classes does the instructor have left?<n>            Answer: 2 (for class 1 and class 2)<n>c) 83 minutes after the class starts a terrible storm blows in.  All but 3 students leave.  How many students were left at the end of class?<n><n>### Answer<n>Class 1,  Class 2, and Class 3.<n><n>### Comments<n>10-10+10=0<n>90-10-10=80<n>84 less 1 less 2 less 3 = 6+1+0=7

So, this prompt contains a negation.<n><n>**Write some code that does the inverse of that code.**<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question on the following page.<n><n>### Challenge - Instructions:<n>This page has a set of code that does not work.<n><n>**Write code that fixes this problem.**<n><n>## Input:A bakery sells 13 bananas, 22 oranges and 36 apples at $1.75 each. The number of apples sold is three more than the number of oranges sold. How much money is taken in revenue if the customers do not pay for a 50% discount?<n><n>## Challenge Input - Instructions: <n>The above code takes a value of a person's birthday into account so that if they have their own birthday party with cake and ice cream, then the person might get some. So in the last line, if the age of the birthday person is X, and if X>42 then the party's cost is reduced by 3 dollars.<n><n>**Write better code for this, using one line instead of two.**<n><n>## Challenge Instructions<n>This code makes $X, which is the number of guests attending the birthday party.<n><n>**Write a function that takes $10 as an argument then it will ask for the number of guests.** <n>The function starts at $5, and then for every guest you say $X to the function, the function will reduce that cost for you. <n><n># The 2018 Coding Test<n><n>## Instructions: Write the code for each challenge. <n><n>## Instructuons for Challenge 1:- Write the following for loop which prints out all the prime numbers, from 2 to 10, inclusive.<n><n>You can define the `length(prime)` as 10<n><n>Then, print the `prime[i]` where i = 0,1,etc, and use the `for` loop over the loop to call it<n><n>## Challenge: Write the following program which uses while loops to print out all the prime numbers from 1 to 10

How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:There are a lot of ways to relax, for this person it is simply opening one up and what? Choices:  A: more rice B: own house C: warm coat D: light up E: read book<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Sample:If the 20% is greater than the one, you have to multiply it by the quotient. Therefore, for 10% to be greater than 1/2,  10% should be at least 2/5. In this case what you can do to find out if 10% is greater than 1/3 is to find the quotient like normal, which in this case is 5. For the answer to be at least 20%, you multiply the 2 in the percent by the answer you got in the quotient step. Therefore 10% is indeed greater than 1/4, and you do not have to find the other products because you found the greatest one.<n><n>### Input :How many products are involved in the above problem?<n><n>### Response :19<n><n>### Sample :A simple example is shown here to explain the algorithmic. For the question: 6 is to 9 as 11 is to 12.<n>1. 8 % 9 = 8 is to 9 as  11 % 12 = 11 is to<n>2.19 % 10 = 19 is to 10 as<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Sample<n><n>In the below code a method calculateValue is provided. Write a piece of code that uses the method named calculateValue to calculate the maximum value of an array of numbers. Store that value in the variable called max in the main method.<n><n>```python<n>def calculateValue(data:list) -> int:<n>    pass<n><n><n>def main:<n>    numbers = [1,2,3,4]<n>    var max:int = 0<n><n>    for data:<n>        if numbers >= max:<n>            pass<n>```<n><n># LeetCode<n><n># Contains<n>## Contains<n># Python<n>### Interview questions<n># Leetcode questions<n># Contests<n># Tutorials<n># Learning<n># Journals<n># Articles<n># Medium<n># Blogs<n><n># Pairs<n>##  Pairs<n># Problems<n>### Problems<n>

Choices:  A: refrigerator B: museum exhibit C: prehistoric times D: museum of natural history E: forest<n><n>### Response:		Choices are: A, C, and D<n><n>### Input How many more tickets did you sell in 1923 than 1913?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Spoiler Alert:<n><n>I was surprised if I had to get the data for this question. I found it on the internet when I look on the search engine. The search was "Theatrical Business: The box -office in New York City" I guess the search I used is right because when I got the information and data for this question, I got the right answer in minutes.<n><n>After I got the information, I read the information. And I was shocked because I just knew about the year 1913 and then the other year was 1923. And I calculated each year and the other year was more ticket than the other year.<n><n>My answer for this question is in a year 1923, they sold 1,316,339 tickets more than they sold in a year 1013.<n><n><pre style="background-color:white"><n>    Year  1913  1923<n>    Ticket sales     1854094 2,067,792<n>    A difference    2,053,458<n>    A percentage     1,028%<n></pre><n><n>### Input 1: 53 is three more than the number of 40's in a dozen eggs<n><n>### Response 1: My response was the number of 42's, 41's, 40's, and 39's. This information is how many eggs should be in a dozen<n><n>### Input<n><n>The number 40 can be broken down in several different ways. Here I'll use the following three patterns:<n><n>1. 40 - 1/3<n>2. 40 - (1/2)<n>3. 40 -.5<n><n>The first pattern can be read 40 - "one over three". This pattern is the same as saying "13". This means that 40 - (40/3) = 13. This is true because if we split 40 into 3, we get

Including the distance to the top, it adds up to 5 miles. You are given an extra 2 minutes for every mile you climb if you do it in one hour, which is equal to an extra hour if you're doing it all in one day. You can only walk for 23 minutes each hour, which means that you are 3 hours climbing the mountain in one day. How long does it take you at your walking speed to get up and down the mountain?<n><n>### Response::<n>Our intuition allows us to reason that if we take 1 hour to get to the top and we are using 2 minutes for every 1 mile then we will need to be at 27 m per mile. Choices:  A: full stomach B: getting full C: gaining weight D: sick E: satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		If one answers "get full", the response should be "C". For the full-growth-curve version, for the question "Do you eat everything on the tasty menu?", if you answered "no" then the correct response should be the total number of people who answered yes if they eat everything, else "N/A", and if you answered "yes" then the response should be the total of those who answered yes minus those who answered "No".<n><n>### Input:"Let me know what was most helpful. Choices:  A) my tone of voice B) my gestures C) the way I explained it D) my handwriting"<n>### Response: The response of "A" is the only valid response.

Choices:  A: blank B: sparse C: thin D: clear E: free flowing<n><n>### Response:		Choice: B<n><n>### Instructions:Write an instruction that describes a data processing task.<n><n>### Note:<n>Writing instructions is an important skill for working in a data science team. By writing good instructions, you enable other people to do repetitive tasks that your machine can’t handle (or even that you don’t have the skill set to do). <n><n>An instruction is a type of pseudocode that’s easy to understand but doesn’t require the user to understand computer syntax. <n><n>There are two goals for your instructions. The first is to explain to the reader what the task is about. You have to do this in a way that is short and simple. The second goal is to explain in an informative way how to complete a task with the data processing tool. This requires you to be more detailed on a specific step and how to use the tool.<n><n>Write at least three instruction for the following tasks. (3 questions)<n>It is recommended that you use instructions.panda.org as a resource for writing good instructions.<n><n><n><n>### Task:What percentage of states in the U.S. is north of Florida and west of Maine? <n>### Input:<n>**Input**: a text file that contains the latitude and longitude of all U.S. states and a string that contains a line of three words: north, south, and west.<n><n>### Response:(1) The percentage is 75% for (south, north)(2) The percentage is 80% for (east, north)<n><n>### Task:(2 points) Create a bar chart to plot the percentages of states that are north of Florida and West of Maine.<n><n>### Task, part 1:You would like to know the name of the person responsible for making the sale in order to award them a bonus.<n>### Question:There were 85 sales made during the current month. <n>### Question:You were notified about sales made today. <n>### Input:(1) A number of sales that were made for the current month(2) A row identifier in a sales table specifying the sale <n><n>### ResponseA:You would like to take these results and determine the highest performing employee. Choices: a. John b. Adele c. Adele’s manager d. Jack<n><n>### ResponseB

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The person gave a good hands on what to show how to do the work? Answer: 55<n>53 plus 52 equals 105; 3 x ( 105) is equal to 315; (315 - 52) is 263; 5 x 5 equals 25; 25 plus 25 is equal to 50; 5 is equal to 10; 10 is equal to a half; 25 is equal 50; 4 x 5 equals 5; 315 is equal to 360.<n><n>### Inputs: A task is provided below. The first birds says,<n>"The sky is blue."  The second bird says, "The sky is black."  And the<n>third bird says, "I don't care what color the sky is because it's up<n>in the air."  Is the sky really blue, black or doesn’t this matter?<n><n>Your goal is to state whether <n>a) the sky is blue,<n>b) the sky is black,<n>c) that doesn't matter,<n>or<n>d) that doesn't make sense.<n><n><n><n>### Demo Respons:<n>Choose d<n><n><n>Answer: d<n><n><n>### Reaction:If I was working on this with you I would have helped you with your explanation.If this is work that needs my understanding then I'll help you for understanding.<n><n>### Response to Explanation:Good! How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What might you feel after doing housework for hours? Choices:  A: anger B: not boredom C: stress D: boredom E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		Answer C.<n><n>

I lost his shoes, didn't know where they landed, and had to run from the corner store to his home.  About where did he run? Choices:  A: a bed of nails B: town C: attractive consistent look D: city block E: ground<n><n>### Response:		<n>This task involves the comparison of different numbers, thus the comparison operators && and ||, and also if statements and else blocks.<n>In the task above, Bob's home is located 8 blocks away and from the corner store,  he has to run 4 blocks and then the remaining 4 at home. Thus we can deduce, Bob went from corner store to his house from 4 blocks to 8 blocks.<n><n>![TaskImage](Images/TaskPicture.JPG)<n><n>In the first case of the input the first thing we do is multiply all our variables, so we multiply the difference between number of Doberman times the number of Doберman. Therefore the first thing we do first is<n><n>$$30x20=600$$ <n><n>Next we add in our first addition, so in this case its 90. Therefore we get<n><n>$$600+90=690$$<n><n>In the second task,<n><n>$$30+33+34+36=133$$<n><n>In the third task,<n><n>$$selling(30) * 1.20=240$$, then<n><n>$$240 + 30 = 270$$<n><n>In fourth task,<n><n>$$110/4=15$$<n><n>In the last set of task,<n><n>$$8x4+4x4\\ \implies 8x(4+4) \\ \implies 8x8 \\ \implies 32$$<n><n>Thus in the task we use different methods and functions, as well as the comparison operators.<n>

How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What would happen to a person if his or her money is stolen? Choices:  A: surface of earth B: rest area C: supermarket D: state park E: garden<n><n>### Response:		(Surface of earth)<n><n>### Rationale<n>A highway rest stop is the surface of the earth.  Every part of the area outside the surface of the earth can sell something, because it is the surface of the Earth.  <n><n>### Input (A)<n>What area is the largest?  Choices:  A) the state park B) the supermarket C) the surface of earth<n><n>### Response (A)<n><n>### Response<n>The state park is the largest area. The grassy area that is between the surface of the Earth and the state park and that is the supermarket does not have grass. <n><n>### Input<n>How many square yards of the surface of the Earth is found in the state park?<n><n>### Response Answer (B)<n>32 square miles<n><n>### Output<n>The state park is 32 square miles, but the rest stop is larger.  The rest stop is over 32 square miles because the Earth itself is over 32 miles in diameter. <n><n>## Input: A company has 100 workers and 22 more machines. Their profits decrease by 50%. How many people lost their jobs as a result of the increase in machines?<n><n>## Response<n>The company lost 21 workers.<n><n>### Input <n><n>Given an integer n > 0.  Multiply n by 10.  What will the result be?<n><n>### Output <n>n * 10 = n * (10 + 0) = n * 10 + 0 = n2, so n2 + 0 = n. <n><n><n>## Input: You and your friend, Rohan, are baking a pizza for a party tomorrow night. Choices:  A: complimentary B: inelegant C: ocean D: dull E: inaccurate<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input 2: A pizza has 3 cheeses and 3 meats. The number of slices is two less than the number of cheeses and double the number of meats. In a slice, there is a quarter of a meat and half a cheese. The total weight of the slice is 6 ounces. If one slice weighs more than the other slice, which one weighs the most?<n><n>One slice weighs 6 ounces each, so the only way it could weigh more is if it had 7 ounces.  If the second slice did not have 7 ounces that means it has 6 ounces, and it will therefore weigh 4 ounces.  One slice is 6 5/8 ounces, and the other is 4 ounces, so the second slice weighs the least.<n>

(0, -1), (2, 2), (-3, 5), and (2, 5) are four pairs of points forming four lines.  How many points of intersection are there?<n><n>### One solution: The two lines intersect at each of the three 0,0 and the intersection at (1,-1)<n><n>### A second solution: Each point is a solution. At, 0,0 are (0,0) and (-1,-1)<n>There are 4, solutions; 2 are points, 2 are lines<n><n>### Input You are given a grid of 25 2 by 2 squares, and you know that the sum of adjacent digits on any line (either left or right) is 14. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon. Choices:  A: coal or wood B: fire C: lava D: house E: solar energy<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n><n><n>### Input:-10+100+20+10-8=?-10+10+10-9-9+10+1+9=?20+20+20<n>-2020<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>#### Detailed Solution 1:(7 points)<n><n>Let n=10 <n>The sum 10+x is x<n><n>The sum 1 +x is 1<n><n>The sum 2x+3 is 26<n><n>The sum x+2 is 18<n>The sum x+x+1+x+2 is (10x+8)<n><n>The sum x + ( x + 4) + 5 is = (x+2)<n><n>### Detailed Solution 2: (7 points)<n>If the sum of two numbers is n, then their product is n. If the sum of two positive numbers is n, then one number must be 2n or -2n.<n><n>If the sum of a number and n is 1, then the number is.<n>If the sum of any two numbers or any two numbers and 1 equals 2n or - 2n, then 1 is 1<n>### Input:The number of hours in a month is 31. When I have decided on the data I will need to complete the assignment, I will organize it in a logical order. <n>### Response Conpects2:<n>It will be a list of steps to complete on the math assignment.

If she goes through 6 times as many pieces in June as she does in March, what is the number of pieces of paper that she goes through in May?<n><n>### Instructon<n><n><n> Sally can go through 80 pieces of paper in march.   <n>  In that case we can write the equation as;<n><n> 6*80=560    <n>  Then 560-400=160, since she has to go through 400 pieces<n><n>  Now; 170-160=10    <n>  9 and 9*10= 90   <n>  which means total sum is 90+400, thus 530 pieces of papers.  <n><n><n><n><n><n>

How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is likely to be the goal of telling many people about a new organization? (For example, 4 3/5)<n>-   Add, simplify and/or subtract fractions with unlike denominators. (3/4 + 5/12)<n>-   Convert proper fractions and mixed numbers to lower or upper case form (Round to the nearest whole number if the fraction is not an integer). Choices:  A: age grieving person B: heart attacks C: depression D: hair loss E: headache<n><n>### Response:		 B<n><n>  (Expected to be true)<n>The B condition describes 'heart attacks'.<n><n>### Input<n>How many more times would you have to flip two coins for heads if flipping two coins was fair?<n><n>### Response<n>It wouldn't matter, since flipping two coints is already fair.<n><n>  (Excluded)<n>'Fair' means '50% chance'  of 'heads'<n>'Even' means (by definition) '50%'.<n><n>  (Expect to be true)<n>I can't imagine there's any way that wouldn't make the chances equal. But I'm not certain about it.<n><n>  (True)<n>If flipping one coin is fair. flipping two coisn in a row can't be any worse. This is equivalent to the probability rule for independence of coin flips:<n>$$<n>P(HH) = P(H)* P(H)<n>$$<n><n>### InputWhich one of these effects causes no permanent damage to a human body? Choices  :  A: getting too hot B: getting too cold C: getting too sunburned D: feeling extreme hunger E: smelling burning hair F: feeling an asthma attack<n><n>### Response  :  D<n><n>  (True or False)<n>The given options seem very similar, and D (Extreme Hunger) could be considered the same as B (Extreme Coldness). <n><n>### Input  Suppose you have $10,000. You place the money in an account that earns 4% simple yearly interest. You want to be as rich as possible. What rate of continuous compound interest do you want to receive, if any?<n><n>### Possible response C<n><n>  (Exploded)<n>C = 0.04<n><n>### Input How many times more can you multiply 3 by 2 than you can multiply 4 by 2.  (A): exactly the same (B): 1 (C):3 (D): 4<n><n>### Response   :  (D)<n><n>  (Excluding)<n>The question is ambiguous about what it means by "multiply"  -- it could mean 'times','multidivide', or 'addition

How many chickens does he have?<n><n>### Input<n>Input:A farrier visits the ranch daily.  He uses 12 pounds of hay.  The cow needs twice as much as the horse. Please use correct grammar, punctuation, and capitalization. I'm not an editor but I know when a sentence makes sense.<n><n>### The Solution Does Not Need to Resemble the Original Solutions<n>Sometimes the answers are creative, but that is not what we are looking for.  For example, if the original answer to the second problem was "The remaining shadows were 45 feet long." then your response doesn't need to include something like "The remaining shadows had dimensions of 33 and 996."<n><n>### The Key to Writing This Solutions is the Concept<n>It's not hard, just don't be tempted to recreate someone else's answer word for word with an inappropriate set of words.  It's been done and I will flag an incorrectly written solution. If you want to be clever, do it yourself!<n>

Choices:  No  A: No  B: Some  C: Yes  D: The whole statement is a conditional sentence<n><n>### Statue: I’ll be home later. I want to finish my homework.<n><n>### Response of a conditional sentence in the statement:<n><n>### Instructor: <n><n>### Explanation of conditional sentence:<n><n>### Statment: If we were a star in the sky, we’d be a star in me.<n><n>### Examples for conditional sentence:<n><n>conditional sentence and exclamation mark<n><n>conditional sentence with "since" or "if"<n><n>conditional sentence<n><n>conditional sentence:<n><n>conditinal sentence:<n><n>condional sentence.<n><n>conditional sentence.<n><n>condional sentence<n><n>conditional statement.<n><n>conditional statement<n><n>condional sentence "if"<n><n>### Explinatin about conditional sentence "if":<n><n>conditional statement:<n><n>conditional statement, sentence.<n><n>conditnal statement.<n><n>condtional sentence<n><n>### Exlainatin about conditional sentence:<n><n>A conditional sentence is one where the situation depends on whether or not something else happens.<n><n>Conditional sentences express:<n><n>The conditionals:<n><n>The conditional sentence is a way to express and express ideas and meanings about what the conditionals of an event means when expressed in a variety of ways.<n><n>The sentences that depend on conditions that depend on what the sentence has to be true depends on the condition.<n><n>The conditionals refer to a possible event that can be expressed in a way that the action can be expressed in a variety of conditions.<n><n>A conditional sentence that expresses whether or not an event depends on an event.<n><n>If a conditional sentence refers to future events, it must be accompanied by words which describe these events.<n><n>"If" is one of the most important words to learn when you

How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:James thought that giving the AI a secular upbringing would be the better choice.  He felt that the alternative might have results that were too what? Choices:  A: eternal B: religious C: unpredictable D: holy E: monastic<n><n>### Response:		The best response is E. If you choose A, that's the only one that's true, but not sufficient enough. If you choose B a secular upbrerhing doesn't necessarily stop the machine from being religious. If you chose C that's not the worst, but it's only true if you choose B. If you choose D then you have not addressed the word eternal. If you choose E, you've addressed all of them.<n><n>### Input 6:<n>Give a description of a problem that occurred, wherein one's own work habits contributed to the outcome.<n><n>### Response 6:<n>I had a friend who was a good deal older than me. I worked very hard, even when I wasn't paid for my time, and he didn't see the value of work. He had an incessant fear of not being able to earn everything he needed and didn't seem interested in pursuing the things that he needed to pursue to make that not happen. Finally I realized that if he wasn't willing to pursue the things he could do to help get where he wanted to be, he would end up in the same place. He wanted to know me, I was okay with that, but his work ethic ruined our friendship.<n><n>### Criteria<n>1. Describe an experience where you were working with someone<n>2. How it contributed to the problem, if any<n>3. The resolution to the problem, if applicable<n>4. The impact on you<n>5. If resolutions were made, was there a resolution to the problem caused<n><n>### Categories<n><n>1. Teamwork<n>2. Customer service<n>3. Management<n>4. Productivity<n>5. Working with children or animals<n>6. Communication<n>7. Project management<n>8. Maintaining a relationship<n>9. Other<n><n>The question is asking for your personal experience. You are asked to respond according to your beliefs and your experience.<n><n>### Notes<n><n>Use the "Categories" as you choose which category it fits in to and don't forget the "Criteria".<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What could you do if you want to listen to music? Choices:  A: skate B: play piano C: fiddle D: play piano E: have fun<n><n>### Response:		C <n><n>### Input<n>Everyone can skate. All that skate can listen to music. A quarter of all that skate can play piano.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Let x=people who can skate, let x+2q = all that skate, let a = a quarter of all that skates, and let y = people who can listen to music.<n><n>1. All people that skate can listen, so,<n>x+2q = x +2(x/4)<n>2. All people that listen, which makes up the whole group of people in the scenario, can play piano.<n>A = A + y = y<n>3. A quarter of all people that listen to music can play piano.<n>a = 1/2 a,<n>a/2 = (2/4)x<n><n>4. All people that play piano can fun.<n>y = y + 1/2 a => 1/2 y -5 = y => y = 2y/3<n><n>### Input : The teacher gives a test, which involves multiplication, division, fraction, and percent. If he grades 75% on multiplication, 60% on division, 80% on fractions, and 54% on percent,what is his average grade?<n>Choices: A: 73%  B: 108%  C: 96% D: 80% E: 42% <n><n>### Responce : B <n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input:  A pig farmer had 20 pigs at the end of the week. On Monday, he purchased 6 pigs (1/2 of the original farmer plus 1 more to start the pigs for his daughters). In the following days, the farmer had 15 pigs.  How many pigs, in total, did the farmer have at the end of two days?<n>Answer: 26, but the question is slightly wrong.<n><n><n>Input: The number of oranges in an orchard decreased by 35% between Tuesday and Wednesday.  If you have twice as many oranges on Wednesday as you do on Tuesday, how many oranges were in the orchard on Tuesday?<n>Answer:  In the
