Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:One way to relieve your hunger if you live near the coast is to do what? Choices:  A: grill B: go to market C: bring home fish D: eat hamburger E: make bread<n><n>### Response:		What you choose will determine the correct answer. Let's try it again.<n><n>### Input:[If you choose A,the correct answer is "grill".][If you choose B,the correct answer is "[BREAD][If you choose C,the correct answer is"cook"."If you choose D,the correct answer is]bring home fish.But if you choose E,the correct answer is go to market.]<n><n>### Response:[If you choose A the correct answer is grill if you choose B,the response should be "bring home fish",but if you choose C,the answer should be "cook"."If you  choose D,the correct response should be "brought home fish.But if  you choose E,the respnds should say to "go to market".][If you choose A, the correct answer is to "grill".If you chose B,  the correct answer is "brought home fish".If you chose C, the correct answer is "cook".  If you choose D, the  correct answer is to go  "to market".If you selected E, the  correct answer would be to go to the "market".]
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The shelf was showing signs of instability, what should the carpenter fix to avoid any issues? Choices:  A: roof B: corner C: school building D: wall E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		 Answer Choice E<n><n>### Instructions: The first week of school, the fourth and fifth grades each got 20 minutes to run around the playground each morning before school. The kindergarten, first and second grade each got 10 minutes to run around. The next week, the kindergarten class got to run around for 15 minutes, a two-minute increase from the previous week.  The first had also gotten an extra two minutes.  How much more time did the first and fifth grade get per week?<n><n>### Response<n><n>A: 10
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where are all participants likely to need sports equipment? Choices:  A: dicks sporting goods B: sporting event C: mall D: sears E: sporting goods store<n><n>### Response:		A - dicks<n><n>### Input<n>There is a basketball coach that has a total of $5000 to spend on gyms supplies and equipment for the school year of 2019-20. He wants to give the players as much of their personal equipment so he sets his yearly budget to cost $15,480 each year divided by 34 members of the basketball team. The coach only needs to use a total of $9,000 which means he can spend the remaining of the budget on buying uniforms, shoes, basketballs, etc.<n><n>A: There is a sporting goods store that has 5 basketballs for $18, $80 worth of pinnies, $26 worth of shoe strings, and $60 worth of basketball strings.<n><n>B: At the mall there is dicks sporting goods and there 5 basketballs for a total of $300.<n><n>C: Sears only has 3 basketballs for a total $90 and $35 for pinnies.<n><n>D: There is not enough information provided to get a percentage.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The mother finished wrapping the very last gift, she then placed it under the what? Choices:  A: department store B: fraizer fur C: specialty store D: christmas tree E: christmas stocking<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Reference:<n>Rebecca Evanse-Creech. Choices:  A: competition B: blood C: wins D: medals E: erections<n><n>### Response:		B- The man was playfully wrestlting with a woman he was in love with. Therefore, he would be getting erections. As he was playfully wrestling, he is obviously getting into competition with his woman. Also, he is probably going to compete with other men that were going to try to get with this woman in the future. Finally, he can get blood from his love.

The dog went outside every 30 minutes. The dog only had time to soil each area 50% of the time. How many minutes did Rachael stay home and the dog stayed outside the entire time?<n><n><n>### Response<n>30 minutes (2*26 = 52 50%)<n>```<n>27<n><n>11, 4<n><n>14, 2<n><n>21, 5<n>```<n><n><n>### Input <n>Irene had a large vase filled with small flowers. Some of the flowers were yellow, some were brown,and some were white. Irene had 15 fewer yellow flowers than brown flowers, and she had 13 fewer white flowers than brown. She was left with 30 yellow flowers, 23 brown,and 20 white. How many flowers remained in the vase?<n><n>### Response : Yellow + Brown + White<n><n>```<n>21<n><n>15, 13, 2<n><n>30, 21, 3<n><n>27, 28, 2<n>```<n><n><n><n>

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The crab was scuttling but strained when he moved, what was impeding him? Choices:  A: tide pool B: beach sand C: tidepools D: current E: cooking pot<n><n>### Response:		<n>![](exam/exam_answers/question1.png)<n><n>### Instructions:Analyze the following code. What is the value of the variable num after the lines of code run? Choice A, B, or C below.<n><n>### Code:<n><n>```cshtml<n>@{<n>string name="john";<n>int i = 5;<n>string num=name;<n>int num2 = 5;<n>int j=j+i+num2;<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Choices:<n>1. The int variable i takes precedence over the string variable num, therefore it will be used in the line j = j + i + num2. Therefore, the variable num will be initialized to the value of 0<n>2. The string variable num takes precedence over the int variable j, therefore it will be added to the int variable j, assigning it to a new variable with a new value which would be equal to i<n>3. The string variable num would be overwritten with the value of 5, then the result of the line would become 15.<n><n>### Choice:<n><n>```cs<n>var num="C" as int<n>```<n><n>## Solving the Problem<n><n>### Introduction<n><n>### Challenge 1<n><n>### Solution<n><n>### Reasoning behind Solution<n><n>### Challenge<n>

How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:At a state fair judging pigs requires careful what? Choices:  A: verdict B: judging C: responsibility D: evaluating E: prejudice<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The pigs at the fair needed careful what?<n>Careful responsibility.<n>

You should know the first two numbers in the pattern by heart, so just sum up those two numbers and add the rest of the numbers together until you get to the last number in the pattern. That's how much it costs to get people to like pizza. <n><n>### Demosnation: 	  <n>$7\times 56=7$<n><n>$7\times57=402$<n><n>$75\times58=400+402+403+404+405=1816$<n><n>$70\times60=42-45+48-=520$<n><n>$710\times62=151-154+157-202=5

When your cat’s on the porch, you better watch your pants.<n><n>2. When things go wrong, you’re better off than dead.<n><n>3. When I am good I am very, very good, but when I am bad, I am horrid.<n><n>4. What a dilemma: When a lion smells the blood of his lunch, he is hard to satisfy.<n><n>5. When life gives you lemons, you better make lemonade.<n><n>6. The question was when a man is lost, where does he look? The answer has four words. You know that the question must have four words in it too. What is the missing word? The correct answer is: Up.<n><n>### What common word shows up in all of the phrases listed above?<n>If you guessed “when,” you’d be correct! Each of the sentences contains a word that can be used as a “when” subordinating conjunction that introduces a dependent clause. While this isn’t the common definition of “when,” it’s important to know what a dependent/subordinate clause is, how to introduce one, and how to identify them.<n><n>### Dependent Clauses<n>A dependent clause is a group of words that contains a subject and a predicate but cannot stand alone as a sentence.<n><n>**Independent VS. Dependent**<n><n>The cat is white. (Sally paints her nails white.)<n><n>The man is screaming.<n><n>**Dependent VS. Independent**<n>

How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of hosting a crowd? Choices:  A: few people B: pay debts C: individual D: single person E: small group<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Choice:<n><n>### Response<n>#### Choice: <n>We have to take away A + B - C, but we must subtract each one in a different direction since the direction of a number is determined by the sign of the number. This makes the difference -105 since the two numbers are negative and the difference will be negative. <n>#### Choice: C<n>Here we multiply C, divide by 4, and add B, which has a total opposite sign.<n>#### Choice: D<n>We have to take this sign and subtract it from B, but we are multiplying the first number by 0.75. This makes the difference 62.5 since the two numbers have an opposite sign. <n>#### Choices: E<n>We must take away C from -D.<n><n>### Write this expression without dividing.<n>2 × (1 + 1) + (1 + 1 – 2)<n><n>### Instructions:Find the value of the variable.<n><n>### Input：<n><n>### Response：<n><n>### Instuctions:Write a sentence that contains the given vocabulary correctly.<n>### Vocabulary<n>- in front of<n>- to the side<n><n>### Instractions：<n><n>### Input:#-#<n><n>### Response:#-#<n><n>- a few<n>- most <n>- almost<n>- the fewest <n>- the least <n>- as little as<n>- half as many <n>- as many <n>- none <n>- zero <n>- as many as <n>- as well as <n>- as good as <n>- as little<n><n>### The following questions ask about the pictures. Choices:  A: food court B: jerusalem C: new york city D: jewish community E: town<n><n>### Response:		<n>Food court<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple question<n><n>### Instractions:<n>The following is the task.<n>I have two quarters. I toss each into the air to land on the floor. The first time I toss both quarters, they land so that the coin closest to the door is not the same coin as the coin furthest from the door. How many different combinations are possible?<n><n><n>### Response<n><n>The coin furthest from door is $A, furthest from door closer to door is $B, closest to door is $C, closest to door closer to door is called $D, $A $B $C $D all have same relation to $1$, so if the $1$ cent is on top we have $1$ $2$ $3$ $4$ or $2$ $1$ $3$ $2$ $4$ or the coin closer to door is on top.<n><n>### Input<n><n>I have two quaters I toss into the air to land, each time I toss the same two quaters, how are they possible?<n><n>### Response(answer):<n><n>The coin that is furthest from the floor is labeled as A, closest to the floor.<n>The coin that is closest to the floor is labeled B, furthest to the door.<n>The coin between A and B is labeled D, furthest to B closest to the door.<n>A can be matched with B, and D with C.<n><n>#### Input: <n><n>I have a group of 585 friends, but only 211 of them can sit at my birthday party which of the following represents a true relationship on the number line starting from 0<n><n>$0$ to $-1$ to $[1,2]$ to $[2,3,..]$ to $4...$ to $578\to579$ to $580\to581$ to $582\to583$ to $584\to585$ to $586\to587\to780\to712\to$$<n><n>#### Response<n><n>$D$<n><n>### Instrtuction:<n><n>Write a program that demonstrates the number of ways that you could solve a math problem involving

There are always extras violins though.<n>#### D:<n>If you needed someone to sit down and play a violin, then it could be in the violin case, if you wanted the violin player to be available to play the violin during a performance then the violin should be in a violin case.<n>#### E:<n>Every time someone buys a new fiddle, it goes to the music store.

For this, a response can be given.<n><n>![](https://thinksterr.com/d3/gpu6j72vw5m9lf3i?w=878&h=618)<n><n>### Explain:<n>Input: What's greater: 12 or 3 less than 28?<n>Answer: If 28 is divisible by 3, then 28 is an even number and thus 12 is greater than 28.<n><n>### Expansion:<n>Input: <n>Answer:<n>![](https://github.com/thinksterr/gpu61/blob/master/gpu61_img/gpu6m9f1qo393t7o.png)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. The length of the rectangle is 3 inches more than two times the width.<n><n>2. The width of the rectangle is twice its length.<n><n>3. The rectangle's width is twice the length of the rectangle.<n><n>### Response<n>![](https://www.google.com/url?sa=i&url=http%3A%2F%2Fmedia.giphy.com%2Fmedia%2FxT91qCqM966hc%2Fgiphy.gif&psig=AFQjCNHeKYqJKQv-58YfX4zJKv2i4B28ZQg&ust=1550993463522000&sig2=LgCwbY70MnE1hv_XZv0Wjw)<n><n>### Notes<n>*The width can also be expressed as x = 2t<n><n>and then<n><n>(3+2t)+ t = (2t+2t)<n><n>2t+t = 3+2t<n><n>3+2t=3+2t<n>t=0<n><n>(3+ 2x) = 3+2(2x)= (3+4x)<n><n>x=4<n><n>A rectangular shape is made by drawing the line<n><n>3+4x

If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The children saw superman fly overhead, what did they exclaim as a result? Choices:  A: determination B: upper hand C: superior D: higher position E: skill<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n><n>#### B<n> <n>#### C<n><n>#### D<n><n>### Input:[<n>In mathematics, there are various ways to calculate the mean.<n><n>The mean of a finite set of numbers is the value determined by the following formula: The sum of all the numbers in the set divided by the count of the numbers in the set.<n><n>The sum of the set divided by the number of the set is the mode in statistics. This is the most frequently occurring number in the set.<n>The median of the set is the number that divides the set into two equal groups. The middle number of the set is evenly shared by the set. For example, if the set was 1, 5, 8, 11, 18, and 23, 5 would be the median value. The set would be parted equally: one part from the value of 8 and the other part from the value of11. The average is found by using these methods using a formula. You could use the mean or average to find the mode, and then you could use the mode to determine the arithmetic or geometric mean.<n><n>In statistics, mean is used in arithmetic and geometric mean. To find the mean of a set of numbers, you can add and divide. For the mean in statistics (also called the mode) we use the set of numbers and see what number occurs most frequently in the set.<n>Another way to show this is in a set with 3 members, and their values are 1, 2 and 3<n><n>]<n>

On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Why would a person be approached by a lot of people? Choices:  A: care about B: compliments C: know all D: popularity E: understand themselves<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Explanation: As an old saying goes, you reap what you sow. That is, if you give people a way to connect to you, they will approach you. But, why would A person be approached by B people? If you know what it feels like to be approached by B people, then you probably have a lot of friends.<n><n>### Input-  Input: You will get to eat one of your favorite desserts if you complete 3 chores. You ate your dessert last night. How many more can you do before you eat your dessert again?<n>[Acceptable Answers]: Choices:  A) 4 B) 7 C) 9 D) Can't tell because I ate it last night E) Don't know<n><n>### Response-  I have a lot of chores to do before I can eat my favorite dessert.<n>### Explanatıon<n>> First, I have to finish cleaning 450 pancakes! Then, I have to cut 900 feet of grass! After that, I have to rake a lot of leaves!  If I have time after that, I have to clean 350 floors! At this rate, I won't be able to eat my favorite dessert because I did these too much by not having a lot of time to do all the remaining chores.<n><n>###Input: A group of volunteers are cleaning all a mess made by a family of 5 at the beach. Write a response that describes the appropriate steps to finish the steps that were not indicated.<n><n>### Scenario:<n><n>Kim is doing a research project for her Computer Science class. It involves creating an algorithm that will complete different tasks like saving different amounts of money to different savings accounts. She wants to get this project ready for a showcase at the end of the week. She's almost finished, but doesn't know how many savings accounts she has.<n><n>### Steps Kim will need to complete the project.<n><n>* Kim needs to make a database of her savings accounts.<n>* Kim needs to store the total amount saved.<n>* Kim needs a savings algorithm.<n><n>### Task Kim needs to complete the project. <n><n>* Create a database of her savngs accounts.<n>* Create a savings algorithm. <n>* Store the total of her savings.<n><n>### Response.<n><n>She'll need to create a database of her savning accounts first, then store the total amount saved, then create a savings algorithm. _______________________________________________________________<n><n>## Instrucion:<n><n>Write a response that indicates what would happen in each of the following examples. Choices:  A: relaxation B: exhaustion C: energetic D: become stronger E: use energy<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>In my opinion, exercising helps the body, both physically and mentally, to function at its maximum potential and therefore leads straight to relaxation.  My exercise regime consists of a two-hour swimming session 4 times a week. I usually follow this routine of exercise with a yoga session.<n><n>The workout allows me to gain the healthy sweat that I need to increase my endurance level and gain the strength I need. Furthermore, because of it, I feel more relaxed and healthy.<n><n>I am certain that I would never want to do exercise if it did not make me relaxed. It helps me to be energized for the next day.<n><n>### Input<n>What should a good diet include? Choices: <n><n>A: 24% fat<n><n>B: 25% protein<n><n>C: 26% carbohydrate<n><n>D: 27% fiber<n><n>### Response<n>I think a healthy and successful diet includes all of the choices. I would never just choose one type of food, because there are different nutrients included from different types of foods.<n>The foods that I eat are a variety to balance the foods I need.  I need to eat foods that are high in protein to help me maintain my energy. It also helps me to stay healthy. I get my fiber from broccoli, and I get my calcium and Vitamin A from milk products and fish. My protein comes from yogurt. By making these choices, I ensure that I am getting the best health possible from my diet.

Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the man set the cup on a table it must mean that there is no what to balance it, if in this question a what is not needed, it stands to reason that whatever he needed to balance the cup he didn't have.<n><n>### Input<n>The man set the cup.  He lacked what to balance.   It didn't matter: he was a juggler.   Choices: A: tenacity B C: skill D: coaster E: breaking<n><n>It is possible to solve this question by considering which the subject is and what it does.  It took me very little time to see that the subject of sentence 3 is the same as the subject of sentence 1, both being "the man", and the verb tense (present continuous) shows that sentence 1 is in continuous time.  The present tense is also a clue, as the man is juggling.  But there could be more than one man, so we want to know which man.  And we need to know what juggling consists of.  Juggling is a skill, and the verb tense in sentence 2 shows that juggling is not continuous, but rather a single activity that the man is engaged in.  Therefore, the man in sentence 2 must be a performer, not the man in sentence 1, and there are three clues that rule out A since all three clues point to juggling skills being required "to balance" and not the tenacity of the juggler.  We now know the man has no what to balance.  We want to know what he lacks, and we notice that in sentence 1 the man does not have the "whatever he needed to balance the... cup".  There is no what in that sentence, and it would be silly to balance the cup with empty air, so what he lacks must be something that he needs to balance the cup.  The only what that seems relevant to the cup, is in the sentence after the one requiring juggling skills.  "It didn't matter", could be referring to a lack of what to balance the cup since it didn't matter how the cup was balanced.  So the man has no skill to balance the cup.<n><n>But what did the man lack that didn't matter?  If the man lacks something that doesn't matter to him, then he has what he la

Type: 10-15<n><n>## Solve It<n>Solve the following equation.<n><table><n><tr><td><n>Solve for w if x = 10 and y = 7<n></td></tr><n><tr><th><n><td>8<n></td><n></th><n></tr><n><tr><n><td><n>w = 8<n></td> <n></tr><n>  </table><n>Answers are to the right.<n><n><n>Answers are correct!<n><n>### Solve the following equation for y if x = 7 and z = 17.<n><table> <n><tr><n>    <th><n>    z = 94<n></th><n>    </tr> <n><tr><td ><n>y = 94<n><n></td></tr><tr><td><n>y = x<n><n></td></tbody></table><n>Ans. A<n><n>### Solving for x if y = 15 and z = 21.<n><table>  <n><tr><th ><n>z = 36<n></th><n><th ><n>x = 20<n><n></th><n><n></tr> <n><tbody><n><tr><tr><td ><n>x = 15<n></td></tr></tr> <n><th><n>y = 15<n><n></th> <n></tbody> <n>Ans.	B<n><n>### Solutions: Solve for y if x = -1 then a = 2, b = -1, and c = 8<n>1. y = 2<n><n>### Solution: Solve for x if b = 5, c = -1, then a = -4<n>solve for x: y =5. a = 4 and b=-5<n>x = 5+10<n><n>## Review<n><table><n>    <tr><td><n>    What is the answer to the equation: 5  + 13

If there are no other fruit markets, the grapes should be put in the super market.  <n>If the customer has brought grapes on their own, they can be returned to the basket.  <n>If there are no fruit markets to store the fruit, the produce manager must go to the grocery market and bring a fruit market to the super market.<n>```<n><n>### Output:  <n>This exercise is about graves.<n><n>### When you are ready, open the grapes, and put them in the fruit basket.  <n>If you do not know where to put the grapes, please do not open them. <n>```<n>

Choices:  A: one material often recycled B: ripped C: saturated with water D: one dimensional E: crumpled<n><n>### Response:		<n> <n>  A.<n><n>### Input:`When does two more than N fit into 7 times the number of cubes?`<n><n>### Response:`When N equals 7.`<n><n>### Input-<n>```cpp<n>int n = 7;<n><n>bool canBeFit = n%(2*n) == 0;<n>```<n>### C++ Code<n>```cpp<n><n>bool canBeRead = n%(2007) == 0; //if n=7 then canBeRead=true<n>```<n>### Python Code<n>```python<n><n>canBeRead if n==2007 else False<n>```<n><n>### Java Code<n>```java<n><n>import java.math.BigInteger;<n><n>public void main(){<n>    System.out.println(BigInteger.valueOf(2007).mod(BigInteger.valueOf((int) (83/2))).equals(BigInteger.ONE));<n>}<n>```<n><n>## Examples<n><n>* [Ask a Math Puzzle](https://github.com/nathancrutchfield/ask_a_math_puzzle)<n>* [Math Game for Kids](https://github.org/nathancruthfild/math_game_for_kids)

Choose only one language.<n><n>### Difficulty:<n><n>### Demos:<n>D: In this demo I will create a new console application called HelloWorld.ts.<n><n>### Language:<n><n>### Write your code here<n><n>### Output:<n>    <Hello World!><n><n>### D: In this demo I added a second console application in c# called HelloWorld.exe.<n><n>### Output of HelloWorld.exe:<n><n>    `Hello World!`<n><n>### L: When coding in Rust, you can create a variable and specify the memory of its lifetime with the keyword "let".  When a lifetime begins, the variables it holds must also exist until that lifetime ends. Let's create a simple variable named x within the HelloWorld program.<n><n>### Rust Code:<n><n>    struct HelloWorld {<n>        let x: i32;<n>    }<n><n>Create a variable and initialize it to 3<n><n>    let x = 3;<n><n>Save the file as HelloWorld.rs and compile it with the following command.<n><n>    rustc HelloWorld.rs<n><n>After running the executable, you'll notice that the output is only "Hello World" as expected. <n><n>### L2: Now, let's attempt to set a different value for x at the start of the program.<n><n>## Code Incorrect Output Correction:<n><n>    struct RustyWorld {<n>        let mut x: i32 = 0;<n>        let mut y: i32 = x; // set y to the same value as x<n>    }<n>    // create a new object<n>    let mut rw = RustyWorld { };<n>    x = 9;<n>    println!(" x: {} y: {}", x, y); // Prints 9 6<n>    x += 1;<n>    println!(" {:?}", x); // Prints 10<n><n><n>### D2: Next let's execute code in Rust where x is set to 4 and y to 12 before calling x and updating x.<n><n>    struct Greedy

If you want to be able make money, you need to take steps "C" and "D".<n><n>In many cases, you might need to work on steps "C" and/or "D" before you can take step "B".  If you choose to do only one of these three steps before you take step "B" you'll be unlikely to succeed.<n><n>If you're interested in making money, you should know that earning money is a skill that you could hone in the future.  Therefore, the choice to pass course or complete application for a job is not optimal for your future success.<n><n>### Input<n><n>#### Topic:What is so appealing about online classes?<n><n>#### Response:<n>Let' s consider this question and it's answers...  <n><n>##### Input: Students prefer online class to traditional class <n><n>##### Input 2: Online class does not require you to wake up early, or wear nice clothes<n><n>##### Input3: Online class gives you more freedom<n><n>#### Input4: Online class reduces costs, because you will not buy textbook and you can save money on transportation<n><n>#### Input5: Online class lets you focus more than traditional ones<n><n>#### Input6: Online classes are available 24/7<n><n>#### Input7: Online class is flexible<n><n>#### Response: <n><n>The only thing that is required in an online class is the presence of a computer. A traditional class requires that you attend class at a certain time and on a certain day. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:James felt himself losing consciousness.  He was frightened.  He didn't want this.  He was scared of what? Choices:  A: death B: coma C: peace D: forgetfulness E: loss of life<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Instructions for answer the below multiple choice questions:<n>In the first problem, you can add four to each side to make the left side positive and the right side negative, and use (5, 4, 3) as the solution.<n><n>In the second problem, notice that the number of Dobermans is decreased by 55 every month.<n><n>Notice how the difference between the number you gave away last month and the remainder is constant. So if you gave away 123 toothbrushess last month, then in March you'll give away half of the difference, or 61. Then in April, since you gave away 61 in March, you give away half the remainder, or 31 toothbrushes this month. In May, since you gave away half of the remainder in April, you give away half of that, or 15 toothbrushes every month. Then in May you give away your last toothbrushes so the busiest month lasts for a year while the slowest month goes from March to April. Therefore, you would give away 61, 31, 15 and so forth for a year.<n><n>In the third problem, Sally picks 10 seashells on day one, and then picks 3 seashells on each day following. If 330 total were available, how many are left?<n><n>In the fourth problem, each half of the 30 fish is left, so Jordan has 20 and Perry has 20. If we subtract the amount of fish taken from Sally (10), we have 72 fish (20 + 20 + 30). The shadows measure 3m(1) + 3m(t-1), since every hour the shadows have measured 2m(t) + 2m(t-1). In order to calculate the length of the shadows at 6 (6x), you would need an expression that has these terms:<n><n>3m(1)<n><n>0.5m(6-1)<n><n>0(6)<n><n>4m(6-1).<n><n>Therefore, you'd end up with:<n><n>4(3m(1)+0.5m(5)+3m(5)+0)(6

How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:When you play around with your dog they will have? Choices:  A: alive B: health C: fun D: playing dead E: black<n><n>### Response:		<n>You will get a multiple choice question depending on your selection. In either condition the response is still either 'Alive B: Health C: Fun D) Playing Dead or E) Black.<n><n>### Input : What do you want: Choices A: 620 B: 720 C: 820 D: 920 E: 1000 F: None<n><n>### Response<n>Your response determines how long the response period for the next question. In this case it will be an hour.

On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. He would be unable to hold his tools if he injured what? Choices:  A: hostility B: anger C: nose D: fists E: hands<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the table below using the provided words.<n><n>### Words to Use:<n>Input:<n>A: Anger<n>B: Blood<n>C: Fists<n>D: Hands<n>E: Knuckles<n>F: Nose<n>G: Own<n>H: Punch<n>I: Tool<n>J: Work<n>K: Wrong<n>Detailed Solution<n><n><n><n>**C = Hands** --> **H / Own** --> **J / Work**<n><n>***<n><n>### Instrument Usage:<n><n><n><n>### Demanded Features<n><n><n>- [ ] **Appropriately completes the request**<n><n>- [ ] Reject<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would a lizard surprise a person? Choices:  A: new mexico B: forrest C: dessert D: garden E: creek<n><n>### Response:		<n>### B.Creed is the correct answer.<n>### The word 'new' means something recently created. When you think of'surprise' you think of something you did not expect.<n>### C.Dessert is the correct answer.  desert means a dry and sandy region.<n><n>### Explanation:The letters are mixed, but in order. You know that C is correct because it is the 3rd word; this must be the 3rd letter, and can only be the F.<n><n>### Input/Explanation of answer:<n>### A.New Mexico is the correct answer. The word "new" can describe different things. In this question, "new" means'made recently'. The word "mexico" is Spanish for "new."<n><n>### Exercises: Solve exercises 1-6<n><n>### Exercise 1:<n>### The correct way to answer the question is to multiply the first number by the second number.<n>### Example: 11x2=$22<n><n>### Expectation: The correct answer is 22<n><n>##Input 2:<n>Input: What is 3x3?  Choices: A. Nine B. 9 C. 12<n><n>### Response 2:<n>The correct answer is "A".<n><n>### Input 3:<n>Input: Which has greater value, 4 or 3x4. Choices: A: 4 B: 3x4 C: 3x7<n><n>### Response to input 3<n>Input: The correct answer is "A": 4<n><n>- [Solve Exercise 1](solution-1.md)<n>- [Solve input 1](solution1.md)<n><n>## [Feedback](./Readme.md)<n>### Input:If the answer is '1/2' what is the other choice? Choices: A. 5 B. 8 C. 2

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If I had a jar which was likely to spoil if left out, where would I want to put it? Choices:  A: kitchen cupboard B: pantry C: grocery store D: pantry E: refrigerator<n><n>### Response:		C. "Pantry".<n><n>#### Reason: The pantry is where you house food that could go bad otherwise. The grocery store is not a good choice because the food you buy might be there but it could spoil if it stays in your cart at the store for more than an hour or so.  The fridge is not good enough unless the food is already in the fridge. The food would still have to sit out for any amount of time. The pantry is the best choice.<n><n>## Below is an instruction that asks you to select a response.<n><n>### Input<n>If I had a jar of cake batter and I had several baking cups, I would want to use all of them right away.<n>```<n>What did the author write?<n>```<n><n>### Demostration<n>  The cook wants all baking cups to be used immediately<n><n>### Response<n><n>```<n>Demonstration<n>```<n>### Input<n>Today is Saturday.<n>```<n>What day will the author write about next?<n>```<n><n><n>### Demons<n>It will be Monday.<n>### Response<n>If today is Saturday then the next day will be a Monday. If Saturday is Monday, we write about Mondays.<n><n>### Below is an instruction that presents a situation and asks a question that can be answered with multiple choice.<n><n>### Situation:<n>```<n>Today was the third time George walked past the bus stop and didn’t see any buses.  How many times did George walk past the bus stop before he got to a bus?<n>```<n>### <n><n>### Demos<n>Today George went to the bus stop for the third time.<n><n>### Response - 3rd time is the answer<n><n>### Situatition: George is trying to get up the stairs when he slips.<n><n>### <n>### Demos:<n>He slips<n><n>### Response- Slipped<n><n>### Situacion<n>I want to buy a book with a pink cover. If there are too many choices I might accidentally buy a book with another color. To find the book I want, should I search for a purple cover or a light- blue cover?<n><n>### Demonio<n><n>I should search for a purple<n><n>### Response Purple<n>

How many fruit do the farmers buy together if they share equally?  Choices: A: 130  B: 244  C: 271  D: 309<n><n>### Response(s): B <n><n>### Instructions:The students each contribute 36 times as much to the book drive as to the charity.  How many books are donated for the book drive if $7000 is donated for the charity.  Choices:  A. 933 B. 947 C. 406 D. 465<n><n>### Response (s): D <n><n>## Instruction:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n>## Instruction:Write at least 40 phrases in order to complete the instruction (i.e. read a poem).<n><n>## Instruction Response:<n>What is a paragraph?<n>> A paragraph is a collection of sentences<n>> Arranged in a logical, connected order that forms a single topic or point; usually several sentences in a paper.<n><n>Paragraphs have both titles and topics, and their titles tend to reveal their content.<n>> Topic sentence - a sentence that specifies the main idea of the paragraph; the first sentence in the paragraph<n><n>Which of the following is the topic sentence for the following paragraph?<n>> The students gathered around the television and anxiously watched their classmate throw the final pitch. They had been waiting to see this day for a while. Their teammate had never pitched a game in his life. They were praying and hoping he did okay. He had never really played organized baseball before, he had played on recreational league teams. He had always gotten the short end of the stick. He was a fat kid. His parents had never been proud of him, it made them look bad. They always said he was a big disappointment, he was always the problem child, he never followed the rules. He was the black sheep of the family. He was always getting picked on at school...<n><n>> At the end of the game both teams were tied at five. The score in that last inning should have been six, but the umpire made an error

On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. Still, he would have preferred it if the job were what? Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n><n>### Response:		The job closer to John’s home<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration<n><n>Input: What’s 2 times 3?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: What is 24 times 2?<n>Answer: 48<n><n>Input: What does 6 times.25 equal?<n>Answer:.15<n><n>Input: What number does 62 ×.2 equal?<n>Answer: <n><n>### Demension:A number is called a factor of a number b if it divides evenly into number b leaving some value behind. If a factor of a number is also a factor of another number, then how much more does the first factor have to divide by the other factor so that the two factors of the second number are equal to each other?<n><n>### Example:How much more does 5 need to divide by 15 so that 5 is a factor of 15 and 30?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Answer: The factor that is one more than that other factor.<n><n>### Example Question:<n><n>Input: Divide 15 by 5. How much does it need to multiply by 5 to get the same answer as dividing by 15<n><n>Output: The factor is 4<n><n><n>### Example Solution:<n><n>Factor of 45 is 15. Factor of 60 is 5 * 4 = 20. <n><n>* 45 ÷ 15 is 3<n>* 60 ÷ 20 is 3<n><n>To be equal, 45 * 4.<n><n>(Note: 45 * 3 = 135, which is not equal.)<n><n>### Instuction: Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>Input: What division expression is written 1025 = 10 ÷ 52<n>Answer: 12510250<n><n>Input: Divided by 1 means divided by 10<n>Answer: 1<n><n>Input: What expression is equal to 153 – 315<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: What are 25 – 31<n>Answer: 6

On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does a chef do when working in the evening? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: study french cooking C: taste sauce D: prepare food E: thin sauce<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Explained:<n><n>>A<n><n>There is still work to be done in the evening after the chef has finished cooking dinner.<n><n>>B<n><n>The chef is not necessarily only studying french cooking<n>>C<n><n>The chef has not prepared food that is necessary to serve.<n><n>>D<n><n>The chef has tasted sauce in order to ensure that it tastes like it did before.<n><n>>E<n><n>This choice does not explain how the evening is being spent.<n><n>### Explaining:<n>>A<n><n>The chef will cook food for dinner. The chef will prepare the food the day before so that all food is ready to be cooked.<n><n>There is not much to "study" in french cooking. It is not necessary to take notes because all the things to remember are already written down. It is possible that the chef is just learning new techniques.<n><n>>B / C<n><n>The chef is still working long past the hours of dinner time. The chef has to clean the kitchen after dinner if they cooked dinner themselves.<n><n>>D / E<n><n>The chef cannot taste sauce on a cooked dish because the dish may have already been put in a container or plate. The chef puts sauce on a dish with the expectation that the customer will eat the entire dish, sauce and all so the chef does not ruin the taste of the dish by putting "extra sauce" on.<n><n>### Answer:It is not necessary for a chef to taste sauce by the end of the cooking process, instead the chef should taste the sauce during the time in which the sauce is cooked. The chef could also try to taste the dish with the sauce and the sauce would not ruin the taste because sauce is made to go on the side or on the top of a dish. The chef could also wait until the sauce is on the side or on top of the dish and "test sample" the dish.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>Input:There are exactly 125 hours in one month, 52 weeks in one year, and 7 days in every week. In how many days were there in the month of August 1943?<n>Answer: There are 31 days in the month of August. There are

Choices:  A: sneezing B: fatigue C: house clean D: feeling satisfied E: getting good grades<n><n>### Response:		<n>If he had stayed awake, he would have had enough time to finish his work.<n>---<n>### Instruction<n>Please correct the following text as needed:<n><n>```shell<n>The program will tell which word is more frequent. To do this we count number of times each word occurs in every file in set to determine which file contains it more often.<n>```<n><n>### Demstration<n><n>```shell<n>$ cat t-tests.sh<n>for i in ${1:?}; do<n>    echo $i<n>    echo "*"<n>done | while read x<n>do<n>    echo $x<n>    wc -l $x <n>    echo $?<n>    echo $? "lines!"<n>    for f in $(ls $x | sort)<n>    do<n>        wc -l "$f" | echo $?<n>        echo "  $f"<n>    done<n>done<n>```<n><n>## Solution<n><n>Input: The program will tell which word  is more frequent. To  do this we  count number of times each  word occurs in every file  in set to determine which  file contains it more often<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>```bash<n>$ cat t-test-sol.sh<n>for i=$1-1;do<n>    echo $i >&2<n>    echo "^^^"<n>done | while read w<n>do<n>    echo " $w"<n>    ls "$w"* |grep -c "$w"<n>done<n>```<n>---<n>### Test<n>```sh<n>$ bash./t-tests.sh test.txt<n><n>The 2.sh<n>^^^<n>* 2.sh<n>lines!<n>  sh<n><n>There is no.<n>lines!<n>  No<n><n>The test.txt<n>lines!<n>* The test.txt<n>2 The test.txt<n>test.txt<n>The test.txt  The test.txt<n>There is no.  There is no.<n>There is no. there is not.<n>```<n>---<n><n>### Extension<n>```sh<n>t-tests-demo-extensions.sh<n>>for i=$1; do echo ^^^; done |while read l ; do ls "$l"* |  grep -c "$l" 2>&1 ; done<n>1.sh<n>^^^   lines!<n>   sh<n>  <  ><n>  sh<n>

How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What can go on a football field? E<n><n>### Input<n><n>The dog's favorite trick is to jump through a hoop with a ball in its mouth. The dog's owner can make the hoop three times bigger by standing on a ladder and stretching the hoop. Every hour past noon, the dog's leash should be long enough for the dog to stand in the hoop, if he is on the ground. You are the dog's owner. If you have a dog, how much longer does the dog's lease need to be after noon on a Monday?<n>### <n><n>### Response<n><n>Choices: 1.12 hours<n>2.6.86 hours<n>3.7.56 hours<n>4.8.38 hours<n><n>## Test yourself!<n><n>Do you remember all the things you learned in this lesson? Test yourself...<n><n>1. What appliance uses water and detergent?<n>2. To which group of animals does a dog belong?<n>3. How did Jordan and the other person catch so many fish?<n>4. Choose the answer that is NOT correct.<n>	- Which animal is taller than the other?<n>	- B: 45cm<n>	- C: 4500cm<n>	- A: a dog<n>	- B: a dog<n>	5. How long does the dog have to stand in the hoops after noon?<n>	- On Monday, after lunch the dog's leverage (or rope) is 66cm.<n>	- After lunch on Tuesday, the dog's rope needs to be as long as on Monday because he has to stand in the hoope again.<n>	- After Friday, the dog's line needs to be 148cm because the hoop is bigger.<n>	- Saturday and Sunday, the dog's lever needs to be 237cm.<n>	- Monday when the dog stands in the hoop, the dog's tail must be 23cm from the floor.<n>	- If the dog is in the hoop and stands in an upright position, then his tail must be the same height as the rest of his body.<n>

Why 64% and not other percentages?  64% of 625 is approximately 410.<n><n>- How many more books were in the library than were in the sample?  Approximately 15.<n><n>2. 57%<br><n>57% of 100 is approximately 57<n><n>57% of -100 is approximately -57<n><n>59 + 57 is approximately 116<n><n>How many more books are in the library than in the sample?<n><n>116 books more...<n>

Remember that a palindrome is<n>a string that reads the same backward as it does forward. For example, “race” is a palindrome, as is “baclava”. “pancakes” is not a palindrome, but “cakespaces” is.<n><n>### Input and Example:<n>On test day we asked for the students to tell us how much time they spent studying for this test. One such student wrote “six hours”. We did not think this was grammatically correct so we asked him when he studied.<n>“I studied six hours last night,” he responded.<n><n>You are provided a string and need to determine if it is a palindrome or not.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: <n>If the input string is not a palindome, you should return a string with the word "no" and return "true" if the string is a palindome. If the string is a palendrome, you should return the string name with "yes" and return "true".<n><n>### Notes:<n>Check if the string only contains 9 characters by checking if it if length - 1 of length - 2 = 0<n><n>If you have to deal with reversing the string, do it inside of a function or in the same loop. This is easier to understand.<n><n>### Code<n><n><div id="palindromer" class="hints"><n> <p class="error">Hints</p><n><n> <p class="answer" id="palindromes"><n><n> <pre class="code"><span id="palindromereverse"><n> </span></pre><n><n> <pre class='code'>function isPalindrome(str) {<n>    if (str.length % 2 == 0) {<n>        <span class="code">if</span>(str.length - 1 == str.length - 2) {<n>            str = (str.charAt(0) + str.charAt(str.length - 2));<n>            <span class="code"><br></span><n>            <span class='code'>while</span>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;str.length % 3!= 0 && str.

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What can happen to you when eating hamburger from someone that you do not know that does not happen when you usually eat a hamburger? Choices:  A: allergic reaction B: gain weight C: have fun D: heartburn E: food poisoning<n><n>### Response:		What happens to you when you eat hamburger from someone you do not know that would not happen when you are not eating hamburger<n><n>Answer: E: food poisoning <n><n>### Input You can put a shovel on the ground. You can also find a spade somewhere in that place. You can also be holding a shovel.  Which one of these will happen to you if you pick a shovel up? Choices A & C. B. D & F E<n>### Response: which choice will occur if you hold both a spade and a shovel in your hand?<n><n>Answer: D & F<n>### Input: You can use either a pumpkin or a pie. You can also use some candy. You cannot be using pumpkin and candy at the same time.  Which ones of these can happen to you when using a pumpkin pie candy and a shovel? Choices: A & B. E F<n>### Response: Which options could occur by using all three items?<n><n>Answer: B<n>### Input: 2+1 + 3 + 3 + 1 + 7 =? Choices: A. 15 C. 7 B.16 D. 9 E. 17<n>### Response: what happens when all the items in the mix are combined?<n><n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input I bought 6 hats and put them on their shelf and decided that I did not like that hat so I gave it to the neighbor. Did I have the same amount of hats I used to have after I made all 3 pancakes? Choices: A: I did have the same amount of pancakes B: Yes but how many I had when I made pancakes was different. C: I did not have the same amount.  D. No, I did not have the sane amount of hats E. I had the same amount of hamburgers.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: D. How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:When they got out of the car in the mountains he felt like he was breathing fresh air for the first time, he began to do what to enjoy it more? Choices:  A: living B: feeling good C: hyperventilate D: look around E: breathe deeply<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is option D<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Write a function for this task.<n><n>### Task<n><n>Given the number of a digit in a number, print a string of ‘0’s’ and ‘1’s’ for that place.<n>### Notes<n><n>We are assuming an array of 1’s and 0’s. <n><n>Input: 7<n>Output: 0000001<n><n>Input: 5<n>Output: 0101<n><n>### Input<n>Number: 75<n><n>### Output<n>'0000075'<n><n>### Solution<n>Create a function that takes the number as input and the number of digits we want.<n>We will use the index of the array of ones and zeroes to determine the digit we will print as a 0 or a 1. <n><n>### Task 1<n>This function should find the largest prime factor of a number. <n><n>## Task 2<n>Create a function given a number and the length of string representing the number of digits you want, write a string and then a function.<n><n>### Demo<n>Write a script that replaces a digit with the next digit after the current one<n><n>### Output should be:<n><n>3459621<n><n>### Demo Script<n>let a = Number('0123456789AB');<n>let place = Number('000');<n><n>function replaceNumber(input,length,index) {<n><n>    if (length === index) {<n>    console.log('0');<n>    }<n>    else {<n>    let digits = [];<n>    for(let i = 0; i < index; i++){<n>        digits.push("0");<n>    }<n>    for(let j = 0; j < length -index; j++){<n>        if(a[j] == '0' ){<n>            digits.push("1");<n>        }<n>        else {<n>            digits.push(a[j]);<n>        }<n>    }<n>    console.log(digits.join(""));<n>}<n>place.length === 3? replaceNumber(input, place.length, 0) : replaceNumber(input,place.length,1);<n>}<n><n>replaceNumber(34596

Choices:  A: toy store B: story book C: great outdoors D: countryside E: wildlife refuge<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n><n># First, the user gets a score, which is represented by a tuple in the variable'score'.<n>if (giraffe == "cow"):<n>	score=['good']<n>else:<n>	score=['bad']<n><n># If the user says 'yes', set their score to a higher value. If the user says 'no', set their score to lower.<n>if (user_input=='yes'):<n>	score[0]+=1<n>	score[1]+=1<n>elif (user_input== 'no'):<n>	score[1]-=1<n>	score2[0]-=1<n><n># Output the score and the statement the user made with print<n>print(score + "(", user_input, ")" ),<n><n>```<n><n><n>Input: When he was a small child, he called the giraffes mascot a cow, a fond memory of the not what? Choices:  A: driveway B: the event C: scrap heap D: parking garage E: repair shop<n><n>### Response:		Answer E: the repair shop<n><n>## Problem Statement:<n><n>The task given to you below requires the creation of multiple solutions. You are required to solve the problem using multiple approaches.<n><n>### Task:<n>1. Write the problem below to your manager in an e-mail. Provide any additional reasoning as needed.<n>2. Create a separate solution for each of the given methods. (There is no limit to what methods you may create.)<n>3. Explain your solution.<n>4. Describe the benefit of each of your solutions<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a response for the given problem.<n><n>### Problem:<n><n>You are on a sinking lifeboat. It takes 1/3 of your weight to keep you afloat. If you have 200 kg left and need to make it to shore, design a way to safely transport 5000 kg of sand to the shore without putting yourself into a greater danger.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>The first method is to throw sand in the air, catch it in a large empty container, and slowly push it as far as humanly possible. However, this method is quite dangerous and will not transport the 5000kg in one trip.<n><n>I can only move at 50% capacity without overloading. 5000/(1/3) = 16,666kg. I will have to make many trips to shore with this method.<n><n>Next, we can utilize the force of gravity to move sand. I must move to the shore first, then move the full 5000 back. Gravity will do the majority of the work. However, I will still need to push for a short distance to complete the task. I can only move at 1/3 capacity without overloading as well. 5001/3 = 16, 667kg.<n><n>A third option is that I have two people on the lifeboat and can split the load. If we split the load by 2, than we can make it without any issues.<n><n>I can then move the sand to the shoreline as needed.<n><n>Therefore, we can conclude that the sand method is the safest to perform without risk of drowning, but also without causing injury.<n><n>There are further methods that can be

On the hour, each banana halves its speed.) The first banana reaches its destination in 23 minutes. What does all this mean?<n>Answer: It was either 212, 42, or 21, bananas.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>When bananas are doubled their speed, they will travel double the distance. Thus the 23rd banana must have traveled 46 times the original distance in the first hour.<n><n>Then, when they are halved their speed they should have traveled 1/14 times the original distance in an hour. This means that the 21st of the bananas was at its location for 14/2= 7 hours.<n><n>The answer must be either 212 bananas if they started at 0 and they increased at a constant rate. Or 42 bananas if they had half the initial bananas. (Or 21 if they started having 42 bananas.)<n>### Explanaton:<n>The explanation must be at least 4 lines long, and explain the meaning and the logic behind the given statement.<n><n>### Solution:

There’s three cars with their lights on.<n><n>### Response<n>A: They should follow the leader car into any oncoming traffic.<n><n>### Situation:<n>There’s a man driving a taxi with a passenger, and they are just around the corner from a police officer.<n><n>### Input<n>What should the man and the police officer do?<n>Choices: A: pull over.<n><n>### Choices<n>B: tell the passenger to pull over.<n><n>C: pull over one-quarter of a block in front of the police.<n><n>### What would you do if you get a flat tire for a car that is not your own?<n><n>A: Fix it right away.<n><n>B:  Go to a gas station to ask someone to fix it.<n><n>C: Go to a garage to fix it.<n>

You must provide an answer key and an explanation of why your answer is correct.<n>The gentleman most likely lives on a palace.<n>The gentlemen who has 10,000,000 dollars lives on a palace. He would never be caught leaving him residence. He also does not care to make friends with anyone.<n><n>### Disclaimer:The solution provided could be different from the solution chosen by other learners. How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is another term for instituting civil action? Choices:  A: confusion B: complications C: riot D: arrest E: protests<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Explanation:Riots are usually caused by a person who was upset about something and has the urge to protest, but they act before they think and make trouble for everyone else. It is against the law to protest, but there is a way to do it and that is through civil action. Civil action happens when a person has a problem and would like to get it fixed. In civil action a court would have to be involved so the person can go through legal proceedings. Civil action is an organized protest, but you are not using violence. Civil action can be a way to bring the attention of the public to a cause without causing havoc in society.<n><n><n>### Input :Choose the word that best completes the sentence. All of the answers provided are synonyms.  A: abstain B:  abstemious C: acclimate D:  adorn E:  accommodate<n><n>### Response :E<n><n>### Explantion:To accommodate someone is to provide some assistance. For example, if you invite some one over for dinner you would accommodate your guest by doing the dishes and cooking the food, or making sure the house is tidy. You could also accommodate someone in a business environment by offering to assist them. If they need help and you are able, you could accommodate them by doing so.<n><n>### Input  :How is a tern different with than a swallow? Choices A:  Terns lay eggs in winter. B: Terns fly alone. C: Terns lay eggs late in the summer. D:  Terns migrate to the Arctic. E:  Terns spend summer nesting and laying eggs.<n><n>### Response A<n><n>### Explantion:<n><n># Terns lay their eggs late in the summer while swallows build the nests as soon as the weather gets warm.<n># Tern nests resemble cups; however, there is a small opening in the side so that it can be easily filled with water which the eggs need to stay cool.<n>### Instruction  :Choose the answer that best completes the statement or best solves the problem. A: less than B: minus C:  more than D: greater than E: greater than or equal to<n><n>### Instructions for answer

What is the president's weight in pounds?<n><n>### Solution:<n>Father is 300 lbs<n>Mother is 120 lbs<n>Daughter is 60 lbs<n>Add them up<n>1300lbs<n>Subtract Son-in-law 600 (half 1200)<n>Add half of son-in-law's weight 300 (half 600)<n><n>### Rateional and solution:

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does a master carpenter use to put holes in objects? Choices:  A: drill B: learn C: require obedience D: understand E: spoon<n><n>### Response:		A master carpenter drills and requires obedience.<n><n>### Input :What is the last name of a famous writer? Choices: A: Sharp B: Sharp C: Short D: Shut E: Eggs<n><n>### Response :B is the last name of the famous writer.<n><n>### Output :The sum of two even numbers is 34. If you have a two of those even numbers, is it greater or less than 34? Choices: A : less B : greater C: Both are greater D: Both are less<n><n>### Response If you have a two even numbers greater or less than 2 than 34.<n><n>### Summary:<n>

Choices:  A: action B: demonstration C: understanding D: vote E: revolution<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A: action<n><n>### Inputs:A carpenter needs to build a table.  The table needs to be 1/2 the height of the carpenter and 1/4 the width of the carpenter.  In addition, it needs to be 2/3 the mass of the carpenter, 2/5 the width of the carpenters shoulders, and the sum of the widths of the carpenters 2 limps.  What are the dimensions of the table?<n><n>### Response<n>- Height 8, Width 18, Mass 54, Shoulders 11, limps 7, total width 18+4=22<n><n>##<n>### Inputs 1:<n>- Every 100 years the population of the planet Doubles. Population growth is slowing exponentially.  <n>- After 2000 years, there are 800,000,00 people on Doubles, and Doubles's population growth from year 1 to year 2 is 4. The growth then slowing and by year 400 it's 0.1. The last Doubles citizen dies in year  2058.  <n>- Doubles's year 0 begins in AD 1.<n><n>### Input 2:<n>- The growth in humans per year<n><n>### Response 1:<n>- Population Doubles every 15 years from 2020 to 2095<n>- The Doubles are 2,400,00,006<n><n>### Response2:<n>- After 2,000 years, Doubles has 860 billion people<n><n>### Response3:<n>- Doubles is only around 800, million<n><n>### Response4:<n>- Doubles population growth in Year 0 from year 1 to 2 is 4  <n>- After 400 years it's growing 0.1    <n>- Doubles' last citizen dies in Year 2058<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>Input: The marching band has 110 members.  There are 4 times as many percussion players as there are woodwind, and twice as many woodwinds as brass.  How many brass players are there?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where is a lion likely to live? Choices:  A: veldt B: ocean C: savannah D: africa E: jungle<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration:Input:Every hour past noon shaddows from a building stretch an exta 5 feet, starting with 0 at noon. How long are the shaddows from the building 6 hour pas noon in inches<n><n>### Instuctions:  Input: Every hour past nooon shadows from a building strach 5 feet, starting zer at noon. How mane hour past noon are they 6 hours long in inches?<n><n>### Response<n>In the first input, the answer is B. That is, a lion’s natural habitat is in sub-Saharan Africa. However, many are in zoos.<n><n>In the second input, the answer is E. A lion’s natural habit is in sub-Sarah Africa. However there are some lion in zoos in other countries as well.<n><n>In the third input, the answer is C. In 6 hours, the shadows that were initially 0 will now be 5 feet. Then the shadows will be 10 ft.<n><n>In the sixth input, the answer is D. In 6 hours the shadows stretch an extra 5 ft. They start at zero, so their length at the end of 6 hours will be 12 ft.<n>

You cut each pizza into 8 slices with a 1-sided razor. How many slices do you have? You cut each pizza with a 2-sided razor, how many slices do you now have?]<n>A. 7, 14 B. 5, 8 C. 7, 22 D. 5, 23 E. 0, 5<n><n>### Response:[The answer to each question depends on how good your pizza cutter is :D ]<n><n>### Input:(The answer depends on your math ability).<n><n>### Response:(A good mathematician will answer the question, a bad mathematician will avoid it).<n><n>### Input [What is an example of a good mathematician? Write down an answer within 1 minute and answer this question: What is an example of a bad mathematician?]<n><n>### Response [Good mathematician: Andrew Wiles, He discovered Fermat's Last Theorem. Bad mathematician: Someone who just takes a short cut]<n><n>### Input (An example of someone who took a short cut: If I get a 1-meter-high ladder to the roof of a house 30 meters away, I can jump up and reach the roof without the ladder)<n><n>### Response (That is not true because you need to factor in the 50 or so extra meters your speed will travel in the air)<n>
